newsitem.title: USA: Wall Street stocks dip seen short-lived.
newsitem.headline: Wall Street stocks dip seen short-lived.

text.p: The sudden malaise afflicting U.S. stocks has likely been exaggerated by a holiday-thinned market, analysts said, and a rebound is generally expected to occur soon.
Stocks have suffered from a sudden rise in interest rates, set off by a series of surprisingly strong economic reports that have pummeled the bond market over the last two sessions.
Over that time, the Dow industrials have fallen more than 150 points, pulling global stock markets lower in the process.
But analysts generally discounted the move, predicting a recovery could start as soon as Monday.

"I think you'll see the stock market rebound in a big way," said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Van Kampen American Capital. "You're sitting here in January, when a lot of 401(k) money is available. This is going to be viewed as a classic buying opportunity."

The broad sell-off in financial markets began on Tuesday after stronger than expected home sales and consumer confidence reports and gained new vigor today from a robust National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) report.

The NAPM index, which measures manufacturing activity, spooked the bond market by jumping to a 54.0 reading in December from 52.7 in November, showing the economy had finished 1996 with surprising momentum.
The report sent the long bond tumbling 1-10/32, pushing the yield up to a key level of 6.75 percent. Prior to the NAPM release, the long bond had been 1/4 point higher.

"Economists were looking for an abnormally low reading because they thought factories would close for more than a day with Christmas in the middle of the week," said Philip Orlando chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management.
Even after the report, analysts remained skeptical of arguments the economy was running too hot.

"I don't consider it so strong that we're in an economy that's overheating," said Peter Canelo, chief investment strategist at Dean Witter, adding that with the key monthly employment report due January 10, "We'll have much better numbers to look at next week."
Absent a clear signal of inflation, Canelo said he expected stocks would actually benefit from the NAPM surprise.
"Even if bonds remain under pressure, it will eventually dawn on the stock market that this is good news because it improves the outlook for earnings," he said.
Regardless of how the coming sessions unfold, the back-to-back economic surprises have touched off jitters for a market that only recently had dropped its guard on inflation.

"Before this I think most of the market was looking at January as being mostly non-events," Froehlich said. "Now I think you'll be seeing people sharpening their pencils and viewing January's economic releases as very, very important."
